description: Indicates the current voltage of this GPU.
troubleshootingSteps: Verify that the GPU voltage fluctuates appropriately with load (lower at idle, higher under load) using monitoring tools; if it is stuck low or zero, check power cables, PSU capacity, and driver power-management settings.[web:265][web:268][web:269][web:272][web:277]

If the voltage is unstable or causes crashes, especially after undervolting or overclocking, reset the GPU settings to default (remove undervolts) and test stability.[web:264][web:267][web:271][web:274]
Ensure that the power supply unit (PSU) provides stable voltage on the 12V rails and that all PCIe power connectors are securely seated.[web:265][web:274][web:275]

description: Indicates the current speed of this GPU.
troubleshootingSteps: If clock speeds are stuck at idle/2D levels (e.g., 200–300 MHz) during 3D workloads, change the power management mode in the driver control panel to 'Prefer maximum performance' and reinstall drivers using DDU if necessary.[web:269][web:272][web:275][web:278]
Check for thermal throttling; if the GPU is overheating, it will aggressively downclock to protect itself. Address cooling if temperatures are high.[web:270][web:272][web:273][web:276]
Investigate background applications or multi-monitor setups that might force the GPU into a lower-power P-state incorrectly.[web:269][web:272][web:275]

description: Indicates the current temperature of this GPU.
interpretation: A sudden or gradual increase in temperature may affect server functioning and needs immediate attention.
troubleshootingSteps: Clean dust from the GPU heatsink and fans, and ensure the case has adequate airflow (intake/exhaust).[web:270][web:273][web:276]
Adjust fan curves to be more aggressive (run fans at higher speeds sooner) using GPU utilities like MSI Afterburner or driver settings.[web:270][web:273][web:276]

If temperatures remain dangerously high (e.g., >85–90°C for core, >100°C for hotspot) despite cleaning and fan tuning, consider repasting the thermal compound or replacing thermal pads.[web:270][web:273][web:276]
Lower the GPU power limit or undervolt the card to reduce heat output without significant performance loss.[web:264][web:273][web:276]

description: Indicates the percentage of load handled by this GPU.
interpretation: Comparing values across GPUs helps identify the GPU handling the maximum load.
troubleshootingSteps: If load is unexpectedly low during heavy tasks, check for CPU bottlenecks, frame-rate caps (V-Sync/FPS limits), or driver settings that limit performance.[web:269][web:272][web:276]
For multi-GPU setups, verify that the workload is correctly distributed or SLI/Crossfire/Compute profiles are active and configured properly.[web:269][web:272]
If load stays at 100% when idle, scan for malware (cryptominers) or check background applications (like instant replay/recording) consuming resources.[web:269][web:272]

description: Indicates the average speed of the fans in this GPU.
troubleshootingSteps: Verify that fans are spinning and not physically obstructed; if RPM reads 0 but temperature is high, the fan motor or controller may be failed.[web:270][web:273]
Adjust fan curves in software to ensure fans ramp up correctly with temperature; if software control fails, check fan cable connections on the card.[web:270][web:273]
Listen for abnormal noises (grinding, clicking) which indicate bearing failure, and replace fans if they cannot maintain required RPMs.[web:270][web:273]
